fields.Title of Contribution: "That is not behavior consistent with a rape victim": The effects of officer displays of doubt on sexual assault case processing and victim participation
fields.Description/Abstract: Despite the prevalence and severity of sexual violence, case attrition has <br>been identified as a significant issue. Of the cases that are reported to police, <br>only a small portion result in arrest, prosecution, or conviction. Research <br>has revealed that much of this attrition occurs early in the process and <br>that a number of theoretically supported legal (e.g., physical evidence, victim <br>participation) and extralegal (e.g., demographics, victim credibility) factors <br>influence how and whether a case progresses through the criminal justice <br>system. However, few researchers have directly examined the impact of <br>officer doubt on case processing. Whereas legal and extralegal factors <br>represent case characteristics, doubt represents officer cognition about <br>these characteristics. These perceptions can affect how victims are treated, <br>how police investigate the case, and ultimately, the case’s progression <br>through the system. A random sample of sexual assault reports from one <br>police department in a medium-sized jurisdiction in the western U.S. was <br>drawn to examine the expression of officer doubt, as well as its impact on victim participation, arrest, and referral for prosecution while controlling <br>for relevant legal and extralegal factors. The findings suggest that officer <br>doubt is an important consideration in sexual assault case processing, <br>independent of other legal and extralegal factors, and that it significantly <br>impacts the likelihood of arrest and referral for prosecution. Consistent <br>with previous research, police decision-making was also impacted by certain <br>legal factors. Victim participation was not directly affected by officer doubt <br>but it was predicted by extralegal factors. Implications for future sexual <br>assault research and practitioner training are discussed.
